user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of setup_epoll_fd:
```c
static int
setup_epoll_fd (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  int fd;

#ifndef HAVE_MESSAGES
  (void) daemon; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */

#ifdef USE_EPOLL_CREATE1
  fd = epoll_create1 (EPOLL_CLOEXEC);
#else  /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  fd = epoll_create (MAX_EVENTS);
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == fd)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Call to epoll_create1 failed: %s\n"),
              MHD_socket_last_strerr_ ());
#endif
    return MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
  }
#if ! defined(USE_EPOLL_CREATE1)
  if (! MHD_socket_noninheritable_ (fd))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to set noninheritable mode on epoll FD.\n"));
#endif
  }
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  return fd;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. The elements present are standard C or OS/library APIs and project-specific identifiers, not compiler extensions: 

- Preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef, #ifndef, #else, #endif) are standard C preprocessor features, not compiler extensions.
- The (void) daemon; cast to suppress unused-parameter warnings is standard C practice.
- Calls to epoll_create1 and epoll_create and the EPOLL_CLOEXEC macro are OS/library interfaces (Linux epoll API), not compiler language extensions. Their availability is controlled by feature-test macros and build configuration, but they are not compiler language extensions.
- Macros and functions with the MHD_ prefix (MHD_DLOG, MHD_socket_last_strerr_, MHD_socket_noninheritable_, MHD_INVALID_SOCKET) are project-specific symbols, not compiler extensions.
- The _(...) macro commonly used for localization (gettext) is a macro, not a compiler extension.

I also checked for typical compiler-specific language extensions that must be reported (examples: __attribute__, __asm__, __extension__, typeof, __builtin_*, inline assembler, compiler-specific calling conventions, or nonstandard keywords). None of these appear in the code fragment. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
